Award.AbstractNarration:
One of the major scientific achievements of the 20th century was the fusion of Darwin's Theory of Evolution with the study of Population Genetics. This fusion made it possible to use mathematics to explain how traits like color change as a species adapts to new environments. However, to understand more dramatic transitions, the laws of Developmental Biology must also be considered.

This project uses methods from Genetics, Developmental and Evolutionary Biology to find out how one dramatic change occurred during evolution - the origin of a complex trait or the creation of self-fertile hermaphrodites in roundworms. Three factors make this an ideal problem to study: (1) self-fertility is a complex trait that involves independent changes in sexual development and in how sperm become active, (2) roundworms are the most common animals on earth, and many species infect plants, animals or humans, so their ability to evolve new ways to reproduce could significantly affect the environment, and (3) all of the tools of modern Genetics are available for use in the study of these animals.

The famous roundworm Caenorhabditis elegans produces self-fertile hermaphrodites, but is related to several other Caenorhabditis species that instead make females. This innovative project will focus on alterations in just two genetic pathways (one controlling germ cell fate and one controlling sperm activation) to determine if they are sufficient to transform XX females of into self-fertile hermaphrodites.

These studies will provide advanced training for graduate and undergraduate students. They should also reveal how the complex trait of self-fertility evolved in roundworms, which will advance Evolutionary Biology, and help explain how roundworms invade and adapt to new environments.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In this project, we studied the types of changes that occur when self-fertile hermaphrodites evolve from a normal male/female ancestral species. This type of change happens frequently in some groups of animals. It also provides a simple way to study how evolution produces new traits.

We showed that female nematodes need to acquire the ability to activate sperm in order to become self-fertile. Otherwise, the newly evolving hermaphrodites can't use any of the sperm they make for self-fertilization.

By studying one group of roundworms, (in the genus Caenorhabditis), we showed that ancestral male/female species used two different signals to activate sperm. These signals were only produced in males. When the species C. briggsae became self-fertile, it did so by having the newly evolving XX hermaphrodites co-opt one of these two signals, so that it could activate its own sperm. However, when the species C. tropicalis became self-fertile, it did so by co-opting the other signal for use in the newly evolving hermaphrodites.

These results show the importance of co-option at a genetic level. (Darwin had identified co-option as a key to evolution by showing how whole organs that evolved for one purpose could be recruited to play a new function, like the swim bladder in fish, which became our lungs). Forthermore, they demonstrate that the same trait can evolve by two different paths. Most intriguingly, they suggest that the frequent origin of self-fertility in nematodes might be due to the availability of several evolutionary paths that can produce this trait.

Finally, to carry out these experiments, we helped develop new techniques for editing the DNA in genomes of new species, so that we study mutations in critical genes. This method will become a critical part of all comparative evolutionary genetic research.
